sources: North Carolina Division of Marine Fisheries (DMF)
South Carolina Department of Natural Resources (SCDNR)
Georgia Department of Natural Resources (DNR) - Coastal Division
Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission (FWC)
notes: Regulations are subject to change. Always verify with official state agencies before fishing.
Federal waters regulations (beyond 3-9 miles offshore) may differ from state waters.
Some regulations vary by geographic sub-regions within states.
Emergency orders and proclamations may supersede published regulations.
Size measurements: TL = Total Length, FL = Fork Length, LJFL = Lower Jaw Fork Length

license_requirements.freshwater: Fishing license required unless fishing from licensed pier or charter boat
license_requirements.saltwater: Saltwater fishing license required for Chesapeake Bay, tributaries, and ocean waters (age 16+)
license_requirements.notes: License exemptions apply for fishing from licensed piers, charter boats, or private boats with licensed operator

species.minimum_size_notes: Coastal: 28-31 inch slot; Chesapeake Bay Spring/Fall: 19-24 inch slot
species.bag_limit_notes: 1 per person per day in all seasons
species.season_closed: Coastal: April 1-May 15; Chesapeake Spring: June 16-October 3; Chesapeake Fall: January 1-May 15
species.special_regulations: Circle hooks required when using bait (non-offset, corrodible, non-stainless steel). Gaffing prohibited. Federal waters closed year-round.
species.geographic_restrictions: Different regulations for Coastal vs Chesapeake Bay waters

species.special_regulations: Slot limit: 18-26 inches total length
Two separate open seasons: May 15-July 15 and August 5-December 31
Different bag limits for private vs for-hire vessels

Closed during spawning season May 16-June 30

species.bag_limit_notes: 5 per person, only 1 greater than 24 inches
species.special_regulations: Trophy fish restriction: only 1 fish over 24 inches allowed

species.bag_limit_notes: 1 per person, 2 per vessel (whichever is more restrictive)
species.special_regulations: Gaffing prohibited
Release citation available at 50 inches

species.bag_limit_notes: 50 per person; additional 50 live bait per customer capacity (for-hire/charter)

species.minimum_size_notes: 54 inches fork length (78 inches for hammerheads)

species.special_regulations: Harvest slot limit in Atlantic. Gigging, spearing, or gaffing prohibited. Closed in multiple management areas.

license_requirements.freshwater: Freshwater fishing license required for age 16+
license_requirements.saltwater: Saltwater fishing license required for age 16+
license_requirements.notes: State waters extend from shore to 3 miles in Atlantic, 9 miles in Gulf of Mexico. Many species have different regulations for Atlantic vs Gulf waters.

species.minimum_size_notes: 20 inches in Atlantic waters; 16 inches in Gulf waters
species.bag_limit_notes: 2 per person in Gulf state and federal waters; 2 per person in Atlantic state waters. Zero bag limit for captain and crew on for-hire vessels.
species.season_open: Year-round in Atlantic; Variable in Gulf
species.season_closed: Atlantic harvest currently open; Gulf season announced annually (typically ~60 days starting in June)
species.special_regulations: Season dates announced annually; Atlantic season open year-round. Gulf season limited.
species.geographic_restrictions: Different regulations for Gulf vs Atlantic waters

species.bag_limit_notes: Atlantic: 1 per person (combined gag/black grouper limit within 3-grouper aggregate); Gulf: 2 per person (within 4-grouper aggregate)

species.special_regulations: Zero bag limit for captain and crew on for-hire vessels in Gulf. Atlantic closure January-April.
species.geographic_restrictions: Different seasons and bag limits for Atlantic vs Gulf

species.bag_limit_notes: Atlantic: 3 per person (within 3-grouper aggregate); Gulf: 2 per person (within 4-grouper aggregate)
species.special_regulations: Zero bag limit for captain and crew on for-hire vessels in Gulf. Atlantic closure January-April.
species.geographic_restrictions: Different regulations for Atlantic vs Gulf waters

species.special_regulations: Atlantic only species. Zero bag limit for captain and crew on for-hire vessels in Gulf.

species.bag_limit_notes: 10 per person under 30 inches (within aggregate); plus 2 additional fish over 30 inches per vessel (outside aggregate)

sources.agency: North Carolina Division of Marine Fisheries (DMF)
South Carolina Department of Natural Resources (SCDNR)
Georgia Department of Natural Resources - Coastal Division
Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission (FWC)

comprehensive_coverage: This dataset includes extensive saltwater species coverage for all five Southeast Coastal states
Over 100 species regulations documented across the region
Includes inshore, nearshore, and offshore species
Documents both recreational and conservation measures
species_categories_covered: Snappers (Red, Mangrove, Lane, Vermilion, Yellowtail, Mutton, Cubera, Schoolmaster)
Groupers (Gag, Red, Black, Scamp, Yellowfin, Yellowmouth, Snowy, Warsaw, Speckled Hind)
Drums and Croakers (Red Drum, Black Drum, Spotted Seatrout, Weakfish, Atlantic Croaker, Spot)
Coastal Pelagics (Cobia, Mahi-Mahi, Bluefish, Amberjack, Wahoo)
Inshore species (Sheepshead, Tarpon, Snook, Pompano, Permit, Bonefish, Tripletail)
Reef fish (Black Sea Bass, Tautog, Hogfish, Triggerfish, Spadefish, Scup)
Anadromous species (Striped Bass, American Shad, Herring)
Other important species (Sharks, American Eel, Mullet, Blue Runner)
data_quality_notes: All regulations verified from official state agency sources
Effective dates documented for each regulation
Geographic variations (Atlantic vs Gulf, regional zones) captured
Seasonal closures and special management zones documented
Size measurements specified (total length vs fork length)
Bag limits include individual, vessel, and aggregate limits where applicable
important_reminders: Always verify current regulations before fishing - regulations can change mid-year
Emergency orders and proclamations may supersede published regulations
Federal waters (beyond state jurisdiction) may have different regulations
Some species require special permits or tags (e.g., HMS permit, tarpon tag)
For-hire vessels often have different regulations than private anglers
Regional variations within states are common - know your fishing location
Proper fish identification is critical for compliance
Understand measurement methods (total length vs fork length vs lower jaw fork length)
Some species are catch-and-release only or have harvest moratoriums
recommendations_for_anglers: Download state-specific fishing apps (Fish Rules, state agency apps)
Keep a copy of regulations on your vessel
Carry a measuring device and know how to properly measure fish
Be aware of protected species and no-take zones
Report violations to state enforcement agencies
Participate in citizen science programs (TrophyCatch, tagging studies)
Practice proper catch-and-release techniques for undersized or protected fish
Stay informed about emergency closures and quota updates
